S4.T1.caption: Table 1. Mixed-effects logistic regression predicting participants’ invitations in the agency conditions. The interaction term shows that the diversity score was relevant only to participants’ collaborator choices when it was included in the algorithm. Number of observations: 4,383 recommendations. Groups (Random variable): Participants that searched for collaborators (N=193); BIC=2,130.7; logLik: -1,036. Variables were standardized before running the model. Stars indicate the statistical significance of each coefficient: * p ¡ 0.05, ** p ¡ 0.01, *** p ¡ 0.001.
S4.T1.table:
Estimate S.E.
Fixed effects
Intercept -3.17*** 0.14
Recommendation’s rank -1.20*** 0.09
Same gender 0.26* 0.13
Recommendation’s diversity score -0.11 0.09
Including the diversity score in the algorithm (i.e., Treatment) -0.33* 0.17
Recommendation’s diversity score * Treatment 0.95*** 0.14
Random effects
Variance 0.42 0.65
references:
The mixed-effects model (Table 1) confirmed that including fairness criteria in the recommender system’s algorithm caused a significant difference in participants’ collaborator choices. Gender diversity Participants self-reported their gender identity as “Male,” “Female,” or “Non-binary.” Normalized Blau Index
Race diversity Participants self-reported their race as “American Indian,” “African American or Black,” “Asian,” “White,” “Multiple races,” or “Other.” Normalized Blau Index
International diversity We asked participants, “Which country are you affiliated with?”, and they answered using a list of countries provided by the system. We binarized their answers and considered people identified with the US as “domestic,” and people identified with other countries as “international.” Normalized Blau Index
Project skills diversity Participants self-reported their expertise on six project skills relevant to the course using a 5-point Likert scale ranging from “Not at all skilled” to “Extremely skilled.” This metric was calculated using the coefficient of variation for each project skill and then averaged across all six Normalized Coefficient of variation
references: The recommendation system normalized all these metrics and averaged them into one metric, the ‘diversity score.’ While the system calculated this score for each recommendation, it was only integrated into the algorithm of the fairness-aware condition. For our posterior statistical analysis, we averaged gender, age, race, internationality, and ethnicity diversity scores to calculate a “Surface-Level Diversity Score.” In contrast, we calculated a “Deep-Level Diversity Score” using each team’s average of the six project skills’ diversity scores. Appendix Table B.1 details the participants’ attributes and values that we used to calculate teams’ diversity scores.
